title: 107_hr4193
content: The "Crackdown on Deadbeat Dealers Act of 2002" aims to address the issue of a small number of licensed firearms dealers contributing to a large proportion of crime guns. In 1998, a small percentage of dealers accounted for over half of crime guns traced to them. The Act proposes increasing the number of allowed compliance inspections of firearms dealers from once to three times. Increasing penalties on gun kingpins is proposed as part of the "Crackdown on Deadbeat Dealers Act of 2002" to address the issue of a small number of licensed firearms dealers contributing to a large proportion of crime guns traced back to them. The "Crackdown on Deadbeat Dealers Act of 2002" proposes increasing penalties for engaging in illegal firearms business and enhancing sentencing guidelines for certain violations and offenses under title 18, United States Code. According to the Sentencing Act of 1987, the authority is to be followed as if it had not expired. SEC. 5 amends Section 924(a)(3) of title 18, imposing fines and imprisonment for serious recordkeeping offenses related to gun trafficking. SEC. 6 introduces suspension of firearms dealer's license and civil penalties for violations of the Gun Control Act. Subsections (e) and (f) of section 923 of title 18, United States Code, are amended to allow the Secretary to suspend or revoke a license or impose a civil penalty of up to $10,000 for willful violations of gun control laws or failure to have secure gun storage available at the place of sale. The Secretary has the authority to suspend or revoke a dealer's license or impose a civil penalty of up to $10,000 for willfully transferring armor-piercing ammunition. Any person denied a license or facing suspension, revocation, or civil penalty will receive a written notice stating the specific grounds for the action. The Secretary has the authority to suspend, revoke, or impose a civil penalty on a dealer's license for transferring armor-piercing ammunition. The aggrieved party can request a hearing to review the denial, suspension, revocation, or assessment. The Secretary must provide written notice of the specific grounds for any action taken. If the Secretary decides not to reverse a decision to deny an application, suspend, revoke a license, or assess a civil penalty, the aggrieved party can file a petition with the United States district court within 60 days for a de novo judicial review. The court can consider any evidence submitted by the parties, and if it finds the Secretary's actions unauthorized, it can order necessary compliance. The court can order the Secretary to comply with its judgment. SEC. 7. TERMINATION OF FIREARMS DEALER'S LICENSE UPON FELONY CONVICTION. Amends Section 925(b) of title 18, United States Code to change the wording regarding the termination of a firearms dealer's license upon felony conviction.
